Summary:
The patient is a 59-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and previous cardiac bypass surgery (CABG) who presented with MSSA lead infection and septic arthritis of the left knee. The patient is currently intubated in the ICU and has been diagnosed with bacteremia, vegetation on the pacer wire, and septic arthritis. The patient's creatinine (Cr) levels were elevated upon admission, but have improved after receiving high-dose cefazolin and daptomycin. The patient remains febrile despite persistent bacteremia. The plan is to switch to standard therapy with nafcillin/gentamicin/rifampin, but will hold rifampin and gentamicin for now. The patient will continue to have daily cultures while febrile, and an Infectious Disease (ID) consult is appreciated. Orthopedic consultation is also requested for knee evaluation. The patient has a history of CAD with CABG and PCI with stent placement. The patient's ejection fraction is 30-40% and there is mild decompensated congestive heart failure (CHF). There are no immediate plans to extubate the patient as they are going to the lab tomorrow. Consideration should be given to intravenous lasix tomorrow. The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation on coumadin and there are suspicions of possible atrial flutter. High-risk systemic embolization is a concern
